content:
Is there any accessibility setting to get rid of the big blue box?

It's being enough of a problem that I can't really use Zulip as-is.
I don't think there is. FYI the blue box indicates which message is currently focused.

There is no such setting currently, though we are discussing whether one should be added, and also prototyping design changes that would make the focused message indicator more visually subtle.

@Zalathar I'd be interested to learn more regarding why the blue box bothers you so much.

I feel like I'm being asked to explain why putting my hand on a hot stove "bothers me".

Given that, I can't say I even understand what you're asking. What sort of response would be fruitful?

Usually the blue box shouldn't be that irritating (see screenshot). Maybe the box is bigger for you? Does it cover up part of the message? Does it mess with your ability to scroll through messages (e.g. lagg)? Just providing a screenshot would also help.

image.png

Screen-Shot-2022-02-08-at-23.37.00-fullpage.png

This is what it looks like in context. I want to be very clear that I didn't draw that box on the image myself to highlight something; that's what the interface actually looks like normally.

As you can see, even when the box is at rest, it's by far the most prominent part of the page, making it impractical to read or concentrate on anything else on the page until the urgent notification represented by the blue box is dismissed. But since it's not a notification, it can't be dismissed, so reading simply remains impossible.

When trying to read a conversation, things are even worse. Reading requires scrolling, and any scrolling can cause the box to jump around unpredictably, once again demanding attention and making concentration impossible. This jumping effect is often delayed relative to user input, which amplifies the harm.

and any scrolling can cause the box to jump around unpredictably

FWIW, if you scroll using the keyboard (e.g. the arrow keys), the behaviour of the focus box is quite predictable.

maybe I'm dense, but: What purpose does the blue focus box even serve? I would have guessed that its indicating the "currently selected message", and therefore all the "Message Operations" listed in the help apply to the blue-box highlighted message. But most of the ones I tried (U, V) didn't work. The only one that did work was +, for adding a :+1: to the focused message...
okay, : for opening the reactions menu works too.
(boy I wish I had known about that a while ago, that's going to improve some of my current workflows a lot)
u, v both work for me, fwiw
(firefox, linux)
u works for me, U doesn't. I use > quite often. The box is also useful to keep track of where you were in the topic, but it's somewhat unreliable, I guess.

Laurențiu said:

u works for me, U doesn't. I use > quite often. The box is also useful to keep track of where you were in the topic, but it's somewhat unreliable, I guess.

aha, that was the issue: I was using capital letters

if you have some way of applying user css this would disable the box:

.selected_message .messagebox-content {
    box-shadow: none !important;
}
r for example also replies to the thread of the selected message

Zalathar said:

As you can see, even when the box is at rest, it's by far the most prominent part of the page, making it impractical to read or concentrate on anything else on the page until the urgent notification represented by the blue box is dismissed. But since it's not a notification, it can't be dismissed, so reading simply remains impossible.

I'm not dismissing your concern, but I'll state that the blue box basically doesn't impact my ability to focus or read the flow at all. I don't believe it's accurate to phrase it as universally "impossible" or "impractical".

i also find it distracting when using a mouse wheel to scroll. the process of drawing the box and moving it to a different message creates a noticeable pause, which is even more distracting. also, it frequently ends up highlighting a message that's not the one i'm actually reading (because there's thankfully no way that it's tracking my eye position)
So to summarize, the resolution of this issue would be to add an option to disable the blue box completely.

Another option is to do like Gmail and only put a left border instead of the whole box. This overlaps with the topic border, but it might work anyway, or perhaps the selection border could be a bit thicker.
(gmail also puts a bit of drop shadow around the whole border, but way less than the big blue box)

I personally feel like the behavior that the box automatically jumps back into the visible screen area whenever you scroll too far particularly

  • surprising,
  • unnecessary, and
  • unlike anything I've ever seen before in any kind of software or website

If nothing else, there should be an option for disabling this particular behavior. When I scroll in a text editor, my cursor doesn't jump unpredictably into random positions near the end of the screen either whenever it otherwise leaves the visible area.

a drawback of disabling that particular feature, at least with zulip's current read handling, is that nothing will get marked as read unless you make it to the end of the thread or bring the selection box back in view by clicking or using the arrow keys (and I guess this would bring your view back to the box located who-knows-where? That also seems bad).
Interesting. I did not even know that the box was in any way related to what's marked as read. Definitely not obvious, doesn't have to be this way.

I find the border somewhat distracting myself sometimes, but also it is very important to me because I use zulip a somewhat keyboard centric way and its important to know for me what my shortcuts will act on. (In fact I would find it awesome if it was possible to disable mouse input on zulip so that I could use that as an opportunity to figure out how to move focus to the streams list on the left side of the UI...)
You could use zulip-term for a while. I believe it doesn't support the mouse. It shares many keybindings with zulip web.

bjorn3 said:

The experiment was cut short by API limit getting exhausted in 5 minutes :sweat:
That has happened to me before when quickly scrolling. I don't think it happened for me in any other cases. Been a while since I last used zulip-term though.
